key_title: Key to the species of Tecticornia

breadcrumbs.key_title: Key to the main groups of plants in Victoria
Key to the families of Dicotyledons
Key to the genera of Chenopodiaceae

leads.lead_text: Lateral flowers of each cymule male, central flower bisexual
All 3 flowers of each cymule bisexual or female
Articles of branchlets 5 mm diam. or more when fresh, terminated by prominent, spur-like lobes
Articles of branchlets to c. 3 mm diam. when fresh, truncate at apex or with obtuse, shortly spreading lobes
Perianth membranous; style not protruding; inland
Perianth succulent; style hard and protruding in fruit (especially when dry); coastal or near-coastal
Articles of ultimate branchlets obovoid, mostly c. 5 mm long; fruiting articles dry and pithy; pericarp crustaceous, not embedded in woody axis
Articles of ultimate branchlets ± cylindric, mostly c. 10 mm long; fruiting articles thick and woody; pericarp woody and embedded in woody axis
Seed brown to black, tuberculate to granular
Seed white to pale fawn, with concentric rows of prominent, corrugated fins
Opposite bracts of inflorescence united; articles of ultimate branches to c. 7 mm long (rarely longer in H. pruinosa and H. indica)
Opposite bracts of inflorescence not united; articles of ultimate branches 5–10 mm long
Apex of perianth rounded to truncate
Apex of perianth acute, dorsinventrally flattened
Branches and spikes undulate in outline
Branches and spikes very slender, smooth in outline (resembling branchlets of Casuarinaceae spp.)
Seed brown, tuberculate or minutely papillate on dorsal ridge, indistinctly patterned on sides
Seed dark reddish-brown to black, covered all over with concentric, horseshoe-shaped, tuberculate ridges
Flowers fused together and to upperbract; dorsal ridge of seeds with rows of concentric horseshoe-shaped tubercules
Flowers free; dorsal ridge of seeds with rows of loose papillae or minute tubercules
Spikes terminating branches; fruitlets free
Vegetative growth continuing through and beyond spikes; fruitlets united
Articles with obtuse or broadly acute lobes, dull; flowering and fruiting spikes dense; bracts of fruiting spike not shrivelling, the latter rather barrel-shaped and firmly spongy throughout
Articles with shortly acuminate lobes, shining; flowering and fruiting spikes rather loose, bracts of fruiting spike shrivelling with age
Pericarp hard and persistent, completely enclosing seed; margins of bracts often minutely ciliate
Pericarp hardened near apex, but membranous or absent near base; margins of bracts entire
